title: Habakkuk Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Habakkuk chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Habakkuk Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Habakkuk Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who saw the burden mentioned at the beginning of Habakkuk chapter 1?
options: Habakkuk the prophet
Jeremiah the prophet
Isaiah the prophet
Ezekiel the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Habakkuk the prophet
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:1 states that the burden was seen by Habakkuk the prophet.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk cry out to the LORD about in Habakkuk 1:2?
options: Violence and lack of salvation
Peace and prosperity
Harvest and abundance
Justice and mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Violence and lack of salvation
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:2 shows he cries about violence and that God does not save despite his cries.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:3, what is before Habakkuk's eyes?
options: Spoiling and violence
Peace and harmony
Joy and gladness
Righteousness and justice
questions.correctAnswer: Spoiling and violence
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:3 states that spoiling and violence are before Habakkuk's eyes.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1:4 says that judgment goes forth regularly and the law is upheld strictly.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:4 says the law is slacked and judgment does not go forth, indicating injustice.

questions.question: What nation does God say He will raise up in Habakkuk 1:6?
options: Chaldeans
Babylonians
Egyptians
Assyrians
questions.correctAnswer: Chaldeans
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:6 says God will raise up the Chaldeans, described as a bitter and hasty nation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Habakkuk describes the horses of the Chaldeans as swifter than the _______.
options: leopards
lions
wolves
horses
questions.correctAnswer: leopards
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:8 states their horses are swifter than the leopards.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:9, what will the Chaldeans gather as the sand?
options: The captivity
The harvest
The ruins
The treasures
questions.correctAnswer: The captivity
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:9 says they shall gather the captivity as the sand.

questions.question: Who do the Chaldeans scoff at, according to Habakkuk 1:10?
options: Kings and princes
Prophets and priests
Farmers and merchants
Children and elders
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and princes
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:10 states they scoff at kings and princes.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1:11 describes the Chaldean king attributing his power to his god.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:11 says the king changes his mind and attributes his power to his god.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk call God in Habakkuk 1:12?
options: Everlasting, my God, mine Holy One
Mighty King and Savior
Father and Creator
Judge and Redeemer
questions.correctAnswer: Everlasting, my God, mine Holy One
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:12 addresses God as everlasting, my God, mine Holy One.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:13, why is God described as having 'purer eyes'?
options: Because He cannot behold evil or look on iniquity
Because He created the heavens
Because He judges the nations
Because He forgives sins
questions.correctAnswer: Because He cannot behold evil or look on iniquity
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:13 states God is of purer eyes and cannot look on evil or iniquity.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1:14 compares men to fishes of the sea and creeping things without a ruler.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:14 makes this comparison exactly.

questions.question: What do men do with the angle and net described in Habakkuk 1:15?
options: They catch and gather the fishes
They sow seeds in the field
They build houses
They prepare sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: They catch and gather the fishes
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:15 describes men catching fishes with their angle and net.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:16, why do they sacrifice and burn incense to their net and drag?
options: Because their portion is fat and meat plenteous
Because they seek forgiveness
Because they want rain
Because they honor God
questions.correctAnswer: Because their portion is fat and meat plenteous
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:16 says they sacrifice to their net because of their plentiful portion.

questions.question: What question does Habakkuk ask concerning the net in Habakkuk 1:17?
options: Shall they empty their net and not spare to slay nations?
Shall they mend their net and save the fish?
Shall they cast their net into the sea?
Shall they abandon their net forever?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall they empty their net and not spare to slay nations?
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:17 asks if they will empty their net and continually slay nations.

medium.title: Habakkuk Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Habakkuk Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Habakkuk 1:2-4, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's justice?
options: God is aware of injustice and will respond in His timing.
We should ignore injustice since God does not care.
Justice is impossible to achieve, so we must accept defeat.
Human laws are always perfect and need no improvement.
questions.correctAnswer: God is aware of injustice and will respond in His timing.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:2-4 shows the prophet's lament over violence and injustice, but God reveals He sees these wrongs and will act. This teaches us to trust God's timing for justice rather than losing faith.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:5-6 encourage believers to view unexpected challenges in life?
options: Challenges may come as unexpected acts of God to accomplish His purposes.
Challenges are always punishments for sin and must be feared.
Challenges are signs that God has abandoned His people.
Challenges should be ignored and forgotten quickly.
questions.correctAnswer: Challenges may come as unexpected acts of God to accomplish His purposes.
questions.explanation: In Habakkuk 1:5-6, God tells the prophet that He will do a work that will be surprising and hard to believe, showing that God’s ways may include unexpected trials to fulfill His plan.

questions.question: What biblical principle about humility and God’s sovereignty is illustrated in Habakkuk 1:11-12?
options: God is eternal and in control, even when human powers rise and fall.
Human strength is greater than God’s power.
God changes His mind according to human wishes.
We can rely on human wisdom over divine guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: God is eternal and in control, even when human powers rise and fall.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:11-12 acknowledges God’s eternal nature and that even powerful nations are established by Him for judgment or correction, reminding believers to submit humbly to His sovereignty.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:13 teach us about God's holiness and our trust during times of evil?
options: God is holy and does not tolerate evil, so we should trust His justice even when it seems delayed.
God overlooks evil and is indifferent to suffering.
God approves of evil to test us endlessly.
God is unaware of what happens on earth.
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and does not tolerate evil, so we should trust His justice even when it seems delayed.
questions.explanation: The verse says God is too pure to look on evil and questions why He seems silent, teaching believers to trust that God’s holiness means He will act justly in His perfect timing.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the apparent triumph of the wicked. Based on Habakkuk 1:15-17, what biblical truth can you share about God's perspective on human plans?
options: Those who trust in worldly means for success are misguided; God judges all actions.
Success is always a sign of God's blessing.
God ignores those who prosper unjustly.
Human plans are always beneficial and should be praised.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who trust in worldly means for success are misguided; God judges all actions.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:15-17 describes people rejoicing in their nets and sacrifices to worldly success, but the chapter questions if they will avoid judgment, teaching that trusting in worldly means is misguided.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:7-9 illustrate the reality of spiritual warfare and perseverance for believers?
options: Believers must recognize the fierceness of spiritual battles and remain steadfast in faith.
Spiritual battles are easy and require little effort.
Believers should avoid all confrontations at any cost.
Spiritual warfare is a myth and does not affect believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must recognize the fierceness of spiritual battles and remain steadfast in faith.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 describe a terrible and swift nation symbolizing fierce opposition, reminding Christians to be aware of spiritual challenges and to persevere in faith.

questions.question: Based on Habakkuk 1:10, what attitude should believers have toward worldly powers that oppose God’s will?
options: God’s people can trust that worldly powers are temporary and will be overcome by God’s plan.
Worldly powers are invincible and should be feared above all.
Believers must imitate worldly powers to succeed.
Worldly powers always act righteously and deserve honor.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s people can trust that worldly powers are temporary and will be overcome by God’s plan.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 shows worldly rulers being mocked and their strongholds taken, illustrating that earthly powers are temporary and God’s plan will ultimately prevail.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1 teaches that God sometimes uses nations to correct His people as part of His judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:12 states that God ordained the Chaldeans for judgment and correction, showing that God can use nations as instruments to discipline His people.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1 encourages believers to question God when they do not understand His ways.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The entire chapter begins with Habakkuk questioning God about violence and injustice (1:2-3), demonstrating that it is acceptable to bring honest questions to God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Habakkuk 1:8, the horsemen "shall fly as the _____ that hasteth to eat."
options: eagle
lion
serpent
wolf
questions.correctAnswer: eagle
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:8 uses the simile of an eagle hastening to eat to describe the swift and fierce horsemen, emphasizing their speed and power.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:4 teach about integrity and honesty in daily life despite surrounding wickedness?
options: Even when judgment is corrupted, believers must maintain honesty and integrity.
Integrity is unimportant if wickedness surrounds us.
We should imitate the wicked to survive.
Honesty is only necessary when others are watching.
questions.correctAnswer: Even when judgment is corrupted, believers must maintain honesty and integrity.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes a world where wrong judgment prevails, but believers are called to live uprightly regardless of the corruption around them.

questions.question: Based on Habakkuk 1:16, what warning is given about putting trust in material blessings or possessions?
options: Trusting in material things leads to misplaced worship and false security.
Material blessings guarantee spiritual favor.
Possessions are the ultimate goal of faith.
Worship should only be for material success.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in material things leads to misplaced worship and false security.
questions.explanation: The verse describes people sacrificing and burning incense to their nets and drags, symbolizing misplaced trust in material wealth rather than God.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:14-15 metaphorically illustrate the vulnerability of people who lack spiritual guidance?
options: They are like fish caught in a net, vulnerable to destruction without a ruler.
They are as strong as lions, able to protect themselves.
They are like eagles soaring freely without care.
They are as wise as serpents in all their ways.
questions.correctAnswer: They are like fish caught in a net, vulnerable to destruction without a ruler.
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 compare people without guidance to fish and creeping things caught in nets, illustrating their vulnerability without God’s protection.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and persistence can be drawn from Habakkuk 1:2-3?
options: We should persistently cry out to God in prayer even when answers seem delayed.
Prayer is unnecessary when God appears silent.
We should only pray when circumstances are good.
God ignores repeated prayers and cries.
questions.correctAnswer: We should persistently cry out to God in prayer even when answers seem delayed.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk passionately cries out to God about violence and injustice, teaching believers to persist in prayer despite apparent silence.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:5 encourage believers to maintain faith when God's plans seem unbelievable?
options: God’s works may be beyond our understanding but are sure to happen; trust Him.
If we do not understand God's plans, we should reject them.
God never acts in surprising ways.
Faith depends only on visible proof, not trust.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s works may be beyond our understanding but are sure to happen; trust Him.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 tells believers to watch and be amazed because God will do something in their days that they will not believe, emphasizing faith in God’s mysterious plans.

hard.title: Habakkuk Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Habakkuk Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the primary complaint that Habakkuk voices to the LORD in the opening verses?
options: The LORD does not hear cries for justice despite violence
The nations do not worship the LORD
The temple is in ruins
The people have forgotten the law
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD does not hear cries for justice despite violence
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:2 states, 'O LORD, how long shall I cry, and thou wilt not hear! even cry out unto thee of violence, and thou wilt not save!' showing the prophet's frustration with unanswered pleas for justice.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 1:5, what is the nature of the work God says He will do that will be unbelievable to the people?
options: Raising up a foreign nation to execute judgment
Parting the Red Sea
Building a new temple
Sending a prophet to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Raising up a foreign nation to execute judgment
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:5 says God will 'work a work in your days, which ye will not believe,' referring to raising up the Chaldeans as an instrument of judgment.

questions.question: The 'Chaldeans' described in Habakkuk 1:6 are characterized as:
options: A bitter and hasty nation
A peaceful and benevolent people
The descendants of Abraham
Priests of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: A bitter and hasty nation
questions.explanation: Verse 6 calls the Chaldeans 'that bitter and hasty nation, which shall march through the breadth of the land,' emphasizing their swift and harsh conquest.

questions.question: Which literary device is primarily used in Habakkuk 1:8 when comparing the Chaldeans’ horses to leopards and wolves?
options: Simile
Metaphor
Allegory
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:8 uses 'as' to compare horses to leopards and wolves, a classic example of simile.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 1:4, what is the condition of the law and judgment in the land?
options: The law is slackened and judgment never goes forth
The law is strictly enforced
Judgment is swift and fair
The law is newly written
questions.correctAnswer: The law is slackened and judgment never goes forth
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states, 'Therefore the law is slacked, and judgment doth never go forth,' illustrating social injustice.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 1:12 express God's sovereignty over the Chaldeans?
options: God ordained them for judgment and established them for correction
God is unaware of their actions
They act independently of God
God will destroy them immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God ordained them for judgment and established them for correction
questions.explanation: Verse 12 acknowledges God's control: 'O LORD, thou hast ordained them for judgment; and, O mighty God, thou hast established them for correction.'

questions.question: What theological tension is revealed in Habakkuk 1:13 regarding God's nature and the presence of evil?
options: God is pure and cannot look on evil, yet He seems to tolerate the treacherous
God delights in evil
God ignores righteousness
God is not holy
questions.correctAnswer: God is pure and cannot look on evil, yet He seems to tolerate the treacherous
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the paradox: 'Thou art of purer eyes than to behold evil... wherefore lookest thou upon them that deal treacherously?'

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Habakkuk 1:14-16 to describe the way people are caught and controlled?
options: Men are like fish caught in a net and rejoicing over their capture tools
Men are like birds flying freely
Men are like mountains unmovable
Men are like trees growing tall
questions.correctAnswer: Men are like fish caught in a net and rejoicing over their capture tools
questions.explanation: Verses 14-16 compare men to fish caught by angles and nets, who then sacrifice to these instruments, illustrating idolatry and entrapment.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:11, what is the attitude of the Chaldean king towards his own power?
options: He attributes his power to his god
He denies having any power
He gives credit to the Israelites
He blames his advisors
questions.correctAnswer: He attributes his power to his god
questions.explanation: Verse 11 says, 'imputing this his power unto his god,' showing the king's arrogance and idolatry.

questions.question: What is the historical and cultural significance of the 'Chaldeans' in Habakkuk 1:6-10?
options: They were a powerful Babylonian empire known for conquest and cruelty
They were peaceful shepherds
They were the builders of Solomon’s temple
They were nomadic tribes allied with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They were a powerful Babylonian empire known for conquest and cruelty
questions.explanation: The Chaldeans represent the Babylonian empire famous for rapid military expansion and harsh domination in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Habakkuk 1:9 says the Chaldeans' faces shall sup up as the ______ wind.
options: east
west
north
south
questions.correctAnswer: east
questions.explanation: Verse 9 uses the simile 'their faces shall sup up as the east wind,' emphasizing their swift and unstoppable nature.

questions.question: What is the prophetic burden described in Habakkuk 1:1, and how does it frame the chapter?
options: A vision of impending judgment and divine justice
A historical recount of Israel’s kings
A psalm of praise
A genealogical record
questions.correctAnswer: A vision of impending judgment and divine justice
questions.explanation: Verse 1 introduces the 'burden'—a prophetic vision revealing God's plan for judgment, setting the tone for the entire chapter.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 1:7 describes the Chaldeans' judgment and dignity as something that proceeds independently from God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states, 'their judgment and their dignity shall proceed of themselves,' indicating their pride and self-sufficiency apart from God.

questions.question: How does the complaint in Habakkuk 1:3 relate to Old Testament themes about justice and righteousness?
options: It echoes the prophetic tradition of lament over social injustice and violence
It celebrates the prosperity of the righteous
It focuses on temple rituals
It describes agricultural laws
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the prophetic tradition of lament over social injustice and violence
questions.explanation: Verse 3's lament about 'iniquity' and 'grievance' continues the prophetic concern for justice seen in books like Amos and Isaiah.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects a similar theme of trusting God's justice despite apparent delay, as found in Habakkuk 1:2-4?
options: 2 Peter 3:9
John 3:16
Romans 8:28
Hebrews 11:1
questions.correctAnswer: 2 Peter 3:9
questions.explanation: 2 Peter 3:9 discusses God's patience in not wanting any to perish, echoing Habakkuk’s question about God's delay in justice.

theological.title: Habakkuk Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Habakkuk Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary complaint Habakkuk brings before the LORD in Habakkuk 1:2?
options: He cries out about violence and feels God does not hear or save.
He complains about the destruction of Jerusalem.
He questions why the wicked prosper.
He asks for a sign of God's presence.
questions.correctAnswer: He cries out about violence and feels God does not hear or save.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:2 shows the prophet crying out to God about violence and feeling unheard, reflecting the problem of evil and divine justice. Similar themes appear in Psalm 13:1-2, Lamentations 3:1-24, Habakkuk 1:3, and Romans 12:19 where believers wrestle with God's justice and timing.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:5, what kind of work will God do that will be unbelievable to the people?
options: A work among the heathen that will cause marvel and disbelief.
A work of rebuilding Jerusalem's temple.
A work of healing the sick and raising the dead.
A work of giving visions and dreams to the faithful.
questions.correctAnswer: A work among the heathen that will cause marvel and disbelief.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:5 describes God's surprising judgment through the rise of a foreign nation, illustrating God's sovereignty over all nations. This is consistent with God's use of nations as instruments of judgment (Jeremiah 25:9, Isaiah 10:5, Romans 9:17, Revelation 17:14).

questions.question: Who does God say He will raise up as an instrument of judgment in Habakkuk 1:6?
options: The Chaldeans, a bitter and hasty nation.
The Babylonians, a merciful nation.
The Egyptians, a powerful army.
The Medes, a quiet and peaceful people.
questions.correctAnswer: The Chaldeans, a bitter and hasty nation.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:6 identifies the Chaldeans as God's instrument of judgment, highlighting God's control even over pagan nations to fulfill His purposes. This aligns with Isaiah 10:5-7 and Jeremiah 25:9, showing God's sovereign use of nations for correction.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 1:4, what is the consequence of the law being 'slacked' and judgment not going forth?
options: The wicked surround the righteous, leading to wrong judgment.
The righteous become proud and self-righteous.
The land becomes desolate and unfruitful.
The priests lose their authority.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked surround the righteous, leading to wrong judgment.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:4 explains that laxity in law enforcement results in the oppression of the righteous by the wicked, illustrating the breakdown of social justice. This theme is echoed in Psalms 10:18, Proverbs 29:2, Isaiah 59:14, and Romans 1:32.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk describe the horses of the Chaldeans in Habakkuk 1:8?
options: Swifter than leopards and fiercer than evening wolves.
Slower than camels but more enduring.
Gentle and slow-moving.
Covered with iron armor.
questions.correctAnswer: Swifter than leopards and fiercer than evening wolves.
questions.explanation: The vivid imagery in Habakkuk 1:8 portrays the Chaldeans as swift and fierce warriors, underscoring the terror of God's judgment through them. This martial imagery parallels Joel 2:4, Nahum 2:3, Revelation 9:7, and Psalm 18:10.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:11, what does the Chaldean king do after conquering?
options: He changes his mind, passes over, and arrogantly credits his power to his god.
He humbly acknowledges the God of Israel.
He establishes peace treaties with conquered nations.
He offers sacrifices to the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: He changes his mind, passes over, and arrogantly credits his power to his god.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:11 reveals the arrogance of the conqueror who attributes his success to his own god, highlighting human pride and idolatry. This echoes themes in Daniel 5:23, Jeremiah 43:10, Isaiah 47:10, and Romans 1:21-23 about human rebellion against the true God.

questions.question: What attribute of God is emphasized in Habakkuk 1:12 when Habakkuk calls God 'from everlasting'?
options: God's eternality and holiness.
God's invisibility.
God's omnipresence.
God's mercy only.
questions.correctAnswer: God's eternality and holiness.
questions.explanation: Calling God 'from everlasting' in Habakkuk 1:12 emphasizes His eternal nature and holiness, foundational attributes also seen in Psalm 90:2, Isaiah 40:28, Revelation 1:8, and Exodus 3:14.

questions.question: Habakkuk 1:13 states God has 'purer eyes than to behold evil.' What theological truth does this express?
options: God's holiness and inability to tolerate sin.
God's ignorance of human actions.
God's indifference to evil.
God's approval of all actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness and inability to tolerate sin.
questions.explanation: This verse highlights God's absolute holiness and moral purity, consistent with passages like Habakkuk 1:13, 1 John 1:5, Psalm 5:4, Isaiah 6:3, and Revelation 4:8, which affirm that God cannot look upon sin with approval.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 1:14-15, the people are compared to fish caught by a net. What does this metaphor teach about human helplessness?
options: Humans are trapped and powerless before the plans of the wicked.
Humans are as free as fish in the sea.
Humans control their own destiny like fishermen.
Humans are always victorious over evil.
questions.correctAnswer: Humans are trapped and powerless before the plans of the wicked.
questions.explanation: The metaphor shows the helplessness of people caught by the wicked's devices, illustrating human sinfulness and vulnerability. Similar imagery is found in Psalm 9:15, Jeremiah 16:16, Proverbs 1:17, and Nahum 1:15.

questions.question: What do the wicked do in response to their 'net' and 'drag' according to Habakkuk 1:16?
options: They sacrifice and burn incense to them.
They abandon their nets and repent.
They use them only to provide for the poor.
They hide them to avoid detection.
questions.correctAnswer: They sacrifice and burn incense to them.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:16 shows the wicked worshiping their tools of oppression, reflecting idolatry and misplaced trust. This is consistent with Hosea 8:6, Jeremiah 7:9, Ezekiel 20:29, and Romans 1:23 about idolatry and false worship.

questions.question: What question does Habakkuk ask about the nations in Habakkuk 1:17?
options: Will they continually slay nations without ceasing?
Will they establish peace among nations?
Will they repent and seek God?
Will they build lasting kingdoms?
questions.correctAnswer: Will they continually slay nations without ceasing?
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:17 questions the relentless violence of the nations, indicating concern over divine justice and human sin. This theme appears in Isaiah 10:1-3, Jeremiah 46:10, Ezekiel 25:17, and Revelation 6:4.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 1:7, what is said about the judgment and dignity of the Chaldeans?
options: Their judgment and dignity proceed from themselves.
Their judgment is from the LORD alone.
Their dignity is bestowed by Israel.
Their judgment is weak and uncertain.
questions.correctAnswer: Their judgment and dignity proceed from themselves.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:7 indicates the Chaldeans act with autonomous power and pride, reflecting human arrogance. This contrasts with God's sovereign judgment in Psalm 75:7, Isaiah 45:9, Proverbs 16:18, and Daniel 4:30.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk characterize the faces of the Chaldeans in Habakkuk 1:9?
options: Their faces shall sweep up like the east wind.
Their faces are like the sun in brightness.
Their faces show sorrow and remorse.
Their faces are hidden and mysterious.
questions.correctAnswer: Their faces shall sweep up like the east wind.
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Habakkuk 1:9 evokes swift, destructive force, emphasizing the terrifying power of God's instrument of judgment. Similar imagery is found in Job 27:21, Jeremiah 4:13, Nahum 1:3, and Psalm 78:26.

questions.question: What theological tension is Habakkuk expressing in Habakkuk 1:13?
options: God's holiness versus His apparent silence in the face of injustice.
God's omnipotence versus human weakness.
God's mercy versus human sinfulness.
God's wrath versus His love.
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness versus His apparent silence in the face of injustice.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:13 expresses the prophet's struggle with God's holiness and His seeming inaction amid wickedness, a classic problem of theodicy. Related passages include Exodus 34:7, Psalm 10:18, Romans 8:28, and 2 Peter 3:9.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 1:12, what has God ordained the Chaldeans for?
options: For judgment and correction.
For destruction without cause.
For blessing Israel.
For eternal punishment.
questions.correctAnswer: For judgment and correction.
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 1:12 shows God ordaining the Chaldeans as instruments of His judgment and correction, demonstrating divine sovereignty. This is consistent with Isaiah 10:5, Jeremiah 25:9, Romans 9:17, and Lamentations 3:37-38.
